thread.title: Win has Logano breathing easier ahead of Talladega
thread.title_full: Win has Logano breathing easier ahead of Talladega

title: Win has Logano breathing easier ahead of Talladega
text:
Report an error 
In 13 previous starts at Charlotte Motor Speedway, Joey Logano led only 20 of 4,627 laps, had no wins and had a best finish of third. 
All that changed dramatically on Sunday afternoon when Logano led 227 of 334 laps on the 1.5-mile quad oval to win the Bank of America 500 in the No. 2 Team Penske Ford a day after rain postponed the race from Saturday to Sunday. 
More importantly, Logano won a free pass into the next round of the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship. 
With Talladega looming in two weeks, where every lap is a crap shoot, the victory on Sunday handed Logano an extra bonus. 
“This makes Talladega way easier,” he said. “I know that’s on everyone’s mind when this round starts. We’ll get lots of sleep here the next couple of weeks.” 
Logano did it on an afternoon where Chase contenders were dropping like flies. 
Matt Kenseth, who came to Charlotte with a pair of wins in the past four races, had a nightmare afternoon where everything that could go wrong did go wrong. He hit the wall at least four times before parking the No. 20 Joe Gibbs Racing Toyota and finishing 42nd. 
It wasn’t a great day for Kyle Busch, either, as he collided with Kyle Larson at the entrance to pit lane, damaging the No. 18 JGR Toyota and finishing 20th. 
Dale Earnhardt Jr., meanwhile, came into the Chase with a good head of steam in the No. 88 Chevrolet but now his chances of advancing to the next round are on life support after twice hitting the wall on Sunday and finishing 28th. 
Ryan Newman, who last season relied on consistent top-10 results to make it to the final Chase round, wasn’t so lucky on Sunday, with a 15th-place finish in the No. 31 Chevrolet. 
On the other side of the coin, Kevin Harvick kept his string of strong results alive with a second place in the No. 4 Stewart Haas Racing Chevrolet and Martin Truex Jr. jumped into contention to move to the next round with a third-place finish in the No. 78 Furniture Row Chevrolet. 
HAIL TO THE CHAMP 
Memo to the Formula 1 world championship trophy engraver: It’s L-e-w-i-s H-a-m-i-l-t-o-n. 
Nothing, it appears, now stands in the way of Hamilton winning his third championship and his second consecutive title for Mercedes after his victory on Sunday at the Russian Grand Prix on the Sochi Circuit. 
It puts Hamilton 66 points clear of new second-place driver, Ferrari’s Sebastian Vettel, and 73 points ahead of hard-luck Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg. 
With four grands prix left on the 2015 calendar, Hamilton is now just nine points away from claiming the championship in the No. 44 Mercedes. 
His performance on Sunday also puts an exclamatory end to any discussion over who is No. 1 in the Mercedes paddock. 
As much as the racing gods have smiled on Hamilton in the past two seasons they have certainly frowned on Rosberg, and nowhere was it more evident than at Sochi. 
Remember, it was almost universally believed that Rosberg would be the heir to Michael Schumacher at Mercedes and that Hamilton was brought on board to push the young German to multiple championships. 
Well, it hasn’t exactly worked out that way. 
Right from the start of his tenure with the Silver Arrow team, Hamilton made it clear he wasn’t going to be anybody’s No. 2. 
On Sunday when Rosberg finally was able to keep Hamilton behind him on the start after winning the pole position, it was a throttle failure that ended his day and any hope of ever catching his teammate this season. 
Hamilton did have some reliability concerns in the race as well — the DRS was not working on his car — but it was not enough to affect the outcome. 
He recognized that he has been pretty much spared from the mechanical issues that hit Rosberg. 
“Nico has been incredibly unfortunate to suffer the worst,” Hamilton said. 
FINISH LINES 
It seems that Kimi Raikkonen did learn something in his ever-so-brief dalliance with NASCAR. The way he slammed Valtteri Bottas on the final lap at Sochi was pure stock car racing. ....Kurt Busch is having more legal woes as a result of his disastrous relationship with ex-girlfriend Patricia Driscoll. He is being sued by a clothing company which claims it was hurt by its association with the NASCAR driver as a result of the domestic violence allegations. ... Pirelli has signed on to supply tires to F-1 for another three years. Sponsored Links
